marklogic.body:
You're young and that's good. Â I think you will heal quickly. Â It's hard for me to comment on whether or not being on your feet all day with your job will be hard over time. Â It will be initially but I tend to think you'll heal quicker than I did. Â I'm lucky as I'm a software engineer who slouches in a chair all day. Â In your position you're forced to move in all different directions so you'll put extra emphasis on those minor muscle groups in the lower back. Â Those will hurt initially but become stronger.
My experience is this. Â Before surgery I had "trained" myself to bend in VERY weird ways that wouldÂ alleviateÂ any pain when doing various things. Â For example, to pick up something Off the ground I used to stretch my right leg out and then bend sideways outside my left knee. Â The humpty dance. Â I never realized I made all these weird motions until post surgery after I've healed. Â I can now bend straight down and pick something up like a normal movement. Â This was very hard at first because those "normal" movements involved muscle groups I was never really using. Â It took me a while to build those back up. Â That healing was normal muscle pain and fatigue. Â NOTÂ unmanageableÂ Nerve pain.
So back to your situation. Â I think if you focus on posture, don't move at a super fast pace, be conscious of your movements... you'll be just find in your career.
